image.altText: A woman sits in the passenger seat of a car, looking to one side with a serious expression. The windows have rain drops on them.

props.synopsis: People living with disabilities are being coerced into rented accommodation by unscrupulous operators who can drain their NDIS funding and leave them with little, if any, support.

title.children: This nurse has had to rescue clients 'abducted' by unscrupulous NDIS providers

image.altText: A Wallabies player reflects during the Rugby world Cup match against Wales.

props.synopsis: Australia will almost certainly fall in the pool stage of the Rugby World Cup for the first time after being crushed 40-6 by Wales. Follow all the reaction in our live blog.

title.children: Wallabies' World Cup all but over as Wales hands them record loss in pool clash

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Former Wallabies captain Michael Hooper, who is standing in a Stan Sport studio rather than in France after being left out the squad due to injury, has leaped to the defence of Eddie Jones. "A lot is going to come on Eddie, and maybe there's some fairness in that," he says on Stan Sport. "But I've been in the camp. "No one is up for more hours than Eddie. "Eddie is up til 11 at night thinking about how to make the Wallabies team better, and he's waking up at 3 in the morning answering messages "There's no lack of desire from that guy to make that team the best it can be. "People will come under fire, players first, coaches, coaches staff, the greater wider rugby community. "But let's pull the breaks off Eddie. "I hate seeing people booed regardless of who they are. You know that people are putting themselves out there, players, coaches, they're putting their nuts on the line. "Let's not have a crack at the bloke."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Michael Hooper leaps to Eddie Jones defence

children.content: Former Wallabies captain Michael Hooper, who is standing in a Stan Sport studio rather than in France after being left out the squad due to injury, has leaped to the defence of Eddie Jones.
"A lot is going to come on Eddie, and maybe there's some fairness in that," he says on Stan Sport.
"But I've been in the camp.
"No one is up for more hours than Eddie.
"Eddie is up til 11 at night thinking about how to make the Wallabies team better, and he's waking up at 3 in the morning answering messages
"There's no lack of desire from that guy to make that team the best it can be.
"People will come under fire, players first, coaches, coaches staff, the greater wider rugby community.
"But let's pull the breaks off Eddie.
"I hate seeing people booed regardless of who they are.
You know that people are putting themselves out there, players, coaches, they're putting their nuts on the line.
"Let's not have a crack at the bloke."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Disaster for the Wallabies. The Wallabies will exit this World Cup with a whimper - a nightmare for this team. That second half performance was abject. The Stan Spot commentators said Australian Rugby has hit rock bottom. Hard to disagree. Wales get their biggest ever win over the Wallabies 40-6. The Wallabies have never suffered a big a defeat in the Rugby World Cup.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wallabies humiliated in Lyon

children.content: Disaster for the Wallabies.
The Wallabies will exit this World Cup with a whimper - a nightmare for this team.
That second half performance was abject. The Stan Spot commentators said Australian Rugby has hit rock bottom.
Hard to disagree.
Wales get their biggest ever win over the Wallabies 40-6.
The Wallabies have never suffered a big a defeat in the Rugby World Cup.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A bonus-point try for Wales. It was so easy for Wales - whose supporters cheer again as Wales push the maul over the line. Jac Morgan gets the credit, but it's a team score. Anscombe hits the post for the second time tonight. The score remains 40-6. That is a record score for Wales over Australia, and a record defeat for Australia at the World Cup.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 78' Wales push over another score

children.content: (Getty Images)
A bonus-point try for Wales.
It was so easy for Wales - whose supporters cheer again as Wales push the maul over the line.
Jac Morgan gets the credit, but it's a team score.
(Getty Images)
Anscombe hits the post for the second time tonight.
The score remains 40-6.
That is a record score for Wales over Australia, and a record defeat for Australia at the World Cup.

image.altText: A man plugs in a charging cable to an electric car in a basement.

props.synopsis: Adam Scott's apartment complex paid to retrofit its basement so electric vehicles could charge there, which EV owners say has been life changing.

title.children: Adam can now charge his EV in his Canberra apartment building, but it didn't come cheap

image.altText: Man in denim jacket with shoulder-length brown hair and short beard looks serious

props.synopsis: When Aussie rock band Silverchair broke up in 2011, drummer Ben Gillies was left feeling sad, heavy and unsure where to turn. Then he had a frightening anxiety attack while in the surf. This is how he staged a life comeback.

title.children: Silverchair drummer Ben Gillies reveals the ultimatum that would change his life after the band collapsed

image.altText: A dark-grey capsule with a yellow port sits on the ground in the desert.

props.synopsis: A NASA space capsule carrying the largest soil samples ever scooped up from the surface of an asteroid streaks through Earth's atmosphere and parachutes into the Utah desert.

title.children: 'Really historic' asteroid sample returned to Earth as NASA eyes the future

image.altText: Tasha Jordan and Ken Belbin standing next to the Golden Homes sign.

props.synopsis: Two families who sank their life savings into building their dream homes are unable to move in, with one family left living in a shed and the other couch-surfing.

title.children: 'An interesting form of structure!': Surveyors tell Tasha her home is not built to code, but no-one will fix it

image.altText: Qantas planes sit parked at Sydney Airport, with the city's skyline in the background.

props.synopsis: When a customer advocate is described as feckless and a dud it should be a clarion call to fix it. Two years after the Aviation Consumer Advocate was labelled a "shonky impostor", things are finally heating up, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: The 'shonky impostor' that's meant to help with your airline complaints

image.altText: Chinese tourists posing to camera in the Blue Mountains.

props.synopsis: From today, the Australian government will restart the visa process for Chinese group travellers in what is expected to be a major boost to Australian tourism.

title.children: Chinese visitors to reach pre-pandemic levels by year's end as federal government allows group travel to resume

image.altText: A drone shot shows suburban blocks in South Auckland.

props.synopsis: In Auckland, the council has been running an experiment, and at the heart of it is a bold decision to remove restrictions around zoning — but the New Zealand election could change things.

title.children: Australia has long debated this housing idea, but in Auckland it's already working

image.altText: Usher, wearing sunglasses and a light pink jacket and pants, smiles as he sings into a microphone on stage.

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Usher to headline the 2024 Super Bowl half-time show in Las Vegas. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Fresh off the back of four ARIA nominations, Kylie Minogue spoke to News Breakfast this morning about all things Padam Padam and her new album Tension. Australia's queen of pop is set to begin a three-month Vegas residency later this year and left the door open to a potential world tour in the future. " We're looking at these things, we're trying to make decisions. I'm trying to think of what to say right now!" Kylie said. "But I would love to tour. We're just trying to figure it out."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Kylie Minogue  tells News Breakfast she would 'love to tour'

children.content: Fresh off the back of
four ARIA nominations
Kylie Minogue
spoke to News Breakfast this morning about all things
Padam Padam
and her new album
Tension

props.alt: A photo of Kylie in a fancy living room in London.

children.content: Kylie Minogue.
(ABC News Breakfast)
Australia's queen of pop is set to begin a
three-month Vegas residency later this year
and left the door open to a potential world tour in the future.
We're looking at these things, we're trying to make decisions
. I'm trying to think of what to say right now!" Kylie said.
"But I would love to tour. We're just trying to figure it out."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Wallabies are all but guaranteed to miss the Rugby World Cup knockout stage for the first time after a 40-6 loss to Wales. My colleague Simon Smale has been live blogging every agonising minute and has called it a "disaster" for the Wallabies. You can catch all the reactions in the ABC Sport live blog below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: BREAKING: Wallabies' Rugby World Cup all but over after 40-6 loss to Wales

featuredLink.title: Live: Wallabies' World Cup all but over as Wales hands them record loss in pool clash

props.alt: Two players console a third team member.

children.content: (Reuters: Gonzalo Fuentes)
The
Wallabies
are all but guaranteed to miss the Rugby World Cup knockout stage for the first time after a 40-6 loss to
Wales
My colleague
Simon Smale
has been live blogging every agonising minute and has called it a "disaster" for the Wallabies.
You can catch all the reactions in the ABC Sport live blog below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: French President Emmanuel Macron says his country will end its military cooperation with Niger after its democratically elected president was deposed in a recent coup. France has maintained about 1,500 troops in Niger since the July coup and refused a request by the new junta for its ambassador to leave. Macron says he's told the ousted president that they are also pulling their ambassador out. He's noted that France's military presence in the country was in response to a request from Niger's government at the time.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: France to pull troops out of Niger following coup

children.content: French President
Emmanuel Macron

after its democratically elected president was deposed in a recent coup.
France
has maintained about 1,500 troops in Niger since the
July
coup and refused a request by the new junta for its ambassador to leave.
Macron says he's told the ousted president that they are
also pulling their ambassador out.
He's noted that France's military presence in the country was in response to a request from Niger's government at the time.

props.alt: A mid shot of Emmanuel Macron pointing with his right hand.

children.content: Emmanuel Macron.
(Reuters: Yara Nardi/File Photo)

image.altText: A police officer in a balaclava holding a rifle patrols a road in front of a white angel statue.

props.synopsis: Kosovan police said one officer and three of about 30 attackers died in shootouts around the village of Banjska before the siege began.

title.children: Four dead in northern Kosovo as gunmen battle police, barricade themselves in monastery

image.altText: A Carlton AFL player stands on stage with a medal around his neck, and a sign behind him with the image of the Brownlow Medal.

props.synopsis: The AFL's highest individual award, the Brownlow Medal, will be awarded to the league's best and fairest player of the 2023 season. Here's everything you need to know.

title.children: Everything you need to know about this year's Brownlow Medal

image.altText: Composite image Steve Fisher 2003 and 2023

props.synopsis: Twenty years ago, Steve Fisher became the first person in Tasmania to win the legal right to identify himself as a victim-survivor of child sexual abuse. Now, with a groundbreaking report to be handed down this week, he says the reckoning has only just begun.

title.children: Steve was the first Tasmanian to be able to say 'I was a victim' and name his abuser

image.altText: Chinese Coast Guard boats close to the floating barrie

props.synopsis: The Philippines says the floating barrier prevents Filipino fishermen from entering and fishing in the contested Scarborough Shoal.

title.children: China accused of erecting new barrier near disputed South China Sea shoal

image.altText: hands hold colourful leaflets that read Tes 23

props.synopsis: Two big ethical questions have emerged during the Voice to Parliament campaign: is it fair that non-Indigenous people will get the majority say? And is it fair if one group will get something others don't? Paul Formosa explains.

title.children: Is it ethical that non-Indigenous people get to decide on the Voice? An ethicist explains

image.altText: A man on a motorbike is surrounded by bushfire.

props.synopsis: The emergency management minister tells Insiders authorities are better prepared for this summer compared to the months leading up to the Black Summer fires in 2019 and 2020.

title.children: Australia 'much better prepared' for bushfire threat this summer, says minister

image.altText: An almost grey scale illustration of the exterior of Don Dale. Barbed wire is highlighted in red.

props.synopsis: The government has challenged a recent NT Supreme Court decision to award four former detainees almost $1 million in damages, which the judge said showed "the court's disapproval of unlawful force being used on children or youths in detention".

title.children: NT government appealing 'manifestly excessive' damages to former Don Dale detainees

image.altText: a detailed drawing of a crocodile different shades of green, grey and dark brown

props.synopsis: Researchers say a newly-named species of prehistoric crocodile that once roamed central Australia "would've eaten whatever it wanted".

title.children: Eight-million-year-old outback predator named in honour of its hunting prowess

image.altText: close up of ladies hands administering a flu vaccination into persons arm with rolled up sleeve

props.synopsis: Needle phobia can be a major impediment to injection and vaccination for some — but an initiative at a major children's hospital is being expanded to help more patients get the vital support they need.

title.children: Jabs can be a matter of 'life or death', and support's being boosted for those with needle phobia

image.altText: A picture of a smiling young boy and his mother

props.synopsis: Jane Jones felt grief and loss when her son Zac was jailed. They've written a book about the experience to help other parents deal with having a child behind bars.

title.children: There was no support for Jane when her son was imprisoned. Now she's using her experience to help others

image.altText: A woman pushes Natasha Fyles with one hand and pushes a paper plate into her face with the other hand

props.synopsis: NT Police have confirmed they are investigating the incident, which occurred at Nightcliff Markets about 11.40am on Sunday.

title.children: 'Disgusting': Police investigating after NT chief minister allegedly attacked with pancake

image.altText: A night time photo of a Queensland Police Service car with its blue light illuminated.

props.synopsis: Police say a 44-year-old man came to the Fortitude Valley Police Station on Sunday afternoon with a knife wound to his abdomen before being taken to the Royal Brisbane and Women's Hospital in a critical condition.

title.children: Woman charged with attempted murder in Brisbane

image.altText: A computer screen with the scamwatch webpage open on it.

props.synopsis: Scams are everywhere. So how do you protect yourselves? We asked experts from banks, police, telcos and fraud agencies. Here's what they recommend.

title.children: Here are the top tips from experts to protect yourself against scams

image.altText: Camille Bianchi sits listening to someone speaking off camera.

props.synopsis: That a paedophile had worked on a children's hospital ward for almost two decades was Launceston's worst-kept secret. Then one phone call changed everything, setting in motion a series of events that would alter Tasmania forever.

title.children: It took a call between two old housemates to expose a paedophile and change a state forever

image.altText: a woman holds the back of a toddler who is pushing a stroller along a footpath

props.synopsis: There are about 120 children and young people living in arrangements designed to be short-term but often result in stays of more than a year, with supervision provided by unaccredited labour hire staff.

title.children: 'Get kids out of hotels': Children caught up in foster care crisis to give evidence at NSW inquiry

image.altText: A woman in a purple tshirt and dark blue jeans sits on a fallen tree stump by a river in bushland

props.synopsis: Psychiatrists and psychologists from Ukraine say the strategies and tools used to treat mental illness in regional NSW can work for those struggling with access due to war in their homeland.

title.children: How 'powerful' mental health insights from Australians could help traumatised Ukrainians

image.altText: Mourners crying during a funeral.

props.synopsis: Israeli forces kill two Palestinians, including a fighter of the Islamist Hamas group, during a raid on a refugee camp in the occupied West Bank, emergency workers and Hamas said.

title.children: Two Palestinians killed by Israeli forces in West Bank

image.altText: Cameras filming a pro-Voice press conference

props.synopsis: More than 50 Victorian and national health organisations say the Voice will positively impact health outcomes for First Nations people.

title.children: Health organisations across the country pledge their support for the Voice to Parliament

image.altText: Lachlan and Rupert Murdoch speak at a press conference

props.synopsis: As Lachlan Murdoch finally becomes chair of Fox News and News Corp, the media conglomerate is still evolving, in multiple countries.

title.children: The Murdoch media empire sprawls across continents. Here's what it looks like in Australia and across the globe

image.altText: A black woman wearing a medal around her neck gives thumbs up next to timer on top of car in street

props.synopsis: Running in only her third marathon, the 29-year-old clocks 2 hours 11 minutes and 53 seconds to pulverise Kenyan Brigid Kosgei's record set in 2019 on a flat, city course in the German capital.

title.children: Women's marathon world record shattered in Berlin
